column1: Greenacres is a city in central Palm Beach County

column2: Frederick E. Bryant – a British agriculturalist
column4: and William Greenwood of the Palm Beach Farms Company in Colorado
column5: bought thousands of acres of land in the Everglades and later along the coast of Lake Worth in 1910. The men sold the land to buyers throughout the United States and Canada
column7: with a $10 down payment and a $10 per month charge
column8: which also included a 25 by 25 ft (7.6 by 7.6 m) parcel on the shore of Lake Worth. However
column9: difficulties involved with farming in the Everglades forced 308 buyers to settle at their properties along Lake Worth
column10: an area that would later become the city of Lake Worth. Until the land boom of the 1920s
column11: these lots were effectively abandoned. Around that time
column12: Lawrence Carter "L. C." Swain of Massachusetts acquired 320 acres (130 ha) of land
column13: with the intention of creating a community for the working class. He initially platted approximately half of the land in 1923
column14: with a plat just west of Military Trail becoming the original section of the city. By 1925
column15: Swain began selling lots for $225.The town was originally incorporated as Greenacres City on May 24
column16: 1926. The name Greenacres was the winning entry in a local naming contest. Upon incorporating
column18: 250 residents. Greenacres City was almost completely destroyed by the 1926 Miami hurricane and again by the 1928 Okeechobee hurricane. Swain died in 1944; Swain Boulevard and L. C. Swain Middle School are named in his honor. In 1945
column19: about 125 residents petitioned for the Florida Legislature to abolish the Greenacres City as a municipality. The legislature passed a bill to dis-incorporate Greenacres City in April of that year
column20: which became a law on April 24
column22: without the signature of Governor Millard Caldwell. Then-Mayor Charles A. Grabowski actively fought the new law
column23: as no referendum to forfeit the town's charter had been held. Additionally
column24: Grabowski accused a resident of starting the dissolution movement out of spite after being denied a homestead exemption and claimed that many of the signatories did not actually own property in Greenacres City. Grabowski also asserted that the pleas of city officials and a large number of residents in favor of remaining a town were ignored.On December 4
column26: a meeting was held to reincorporate Greenacres City. A total of 86 out of 120 registered voters turned out
column27: more than the two-thirds of voters quorum required. The 86 voters unanimously decided to reincorporate. The area's rights as a city were restored
column28: while Greenacres City was officially reincorporated in 1947. Over the subsequent decades
column29: Greenacres City eventually expanded to 6 sq mi (16 km2) through annexation. In the 1960s
column30: a city hall complex was constructed at the intersection of Perry Avenue and Fourth Street
column31: while a community center was built nearby. The city hall complex originally included a public library and all other city departments
column32: except for the fire and public works departments. By the 1970s
column33: full-time police and fire departments were established. In response to concerns about future growth
column34: residents approved a bond referendum in 1984 to fund construction of a new city hall
column37: about 60% of voters chose to drop the word "city" from the official name
column38: thus renaming the municipality Greenacres. After the 1990 census indicated a population of 18
column40: city council authorized a special census in 1993
column42: 000 additional residents to the official population count
column43: making Greenacres eligible for funds from the state government of Florida. To commemorate the city's 80th anniversary
column44: the Greenacres Historical Society was formed in 2006
column45: with a museum established two years later. In July 2007
column46: construction was completed on a new city hall and public works facility on Melaleuca Lane.
